ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the various ways in which the history of different parts of the world are connected and intertwined. This class highlights the vast networks that connect our globe and how they developed over time (environmental, trade, migration, etc.).
As the course name implies, I learned about the global phenomena around 1800, including ecological changes, colonialism, empire, nation-states, industry, and revolutions.

I developed the ability to read critically and evaluate a wealth of sources. I learned a lot about the ways in which are world is interconnected and the benefits and costs of trying to write history with that interconnectedness in mind. I definitely know more now than I did before about some of the hidden parts of history.
I learned a lot about the history of the world around 1800. It wasn't just a bunch of facts and dates. It was a model of how the world is connected through many avenues.
How the history has been worked throughout the years.
what global history is
This course focuses on analyzing how globalization has connected and divided people circa the year 1800.
Not really any. The course was very disorganized (dates on the syllabus were not the actual dates, for example).

To be fully honest, almost none. Regarding content, I feel like it was scattered around the globe, and even though the connections between those different moments/places were explored to a certain extent, it sometimes just felt like I was watching History Channel and learning random things about places I didn't know before. The discussions about places/moments I knew (e.g. French Revolution) were bland. 
If anything, I think my TF helped me improve my writing through his feedback.
I learned how to evaluate global history and how to ask important questions about what it means to study history.
How to approach history, the broader themes of the 1800s, how to dissect primary documents and compile secondary research
Lots of discussions. Evaluating different types of sources and how we think about history from all perspectives.
Global history

I learned a great deal about global history around the year 1800. More than this, the class introduced me to a more sophisticated approach to learning history in which you think about the ramifications of every action on other nations. Lastly, I greatly improved my writing skills in the course with the three assignments.
A general knowledge about the world circa 1800, spanning N&S America, Europe, Asia, Africa, & Oceania. Knowledge about how these places interacted with one another.
Deep knowledge of 1800s history, better working understanding of rise of global history and a lot of historical tidbits
I learned about global history, and it was a really cool introduction as a STEM major to a new field of history.

I gained a greater appreciation of the importance of analyzing history through a global lens. In particular, I learned a lot about the French Revolution and how it affected other regions of the world.

I learned a lot of very relevant history that took place circa 1800. I learned a lot about how the world became connected and the events that resulted from those connections. I also learned a lot about how history is written and how biased it can be. I think I developed important critical thinking skills and gained knowledge that helps me understand and contextualize current events.
History globa
How to approach history from a more global perspective
World History around approximately 1800

This course was good for learning more of a holistic view of world history around the time. We covered a lot of regions and themes throughout so do not expect any in-depth information on a particular movement.
I learned how to think about history on a macro-level in terms of connections.
Learned about history circa 1800.
I learned how to analyze primary historical documents and how to apply that information when reading and writing about secondary historical texts.
I learned a lot about global interactions in history
I gained a better understanding of history from a worldly context, and how different historical events relate to each other.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded lectures were a lot at times on top of the readings and I tended to not listen to them if short on time. I would suggest doing more during the nonrecorded live lectures to promote engagement and participation.

Strengths: The pre-recorded lectures and readings were helpful and interesting. I especially enjoyed the lectures on ecology, India, Japan, the Comanche, and the material world. The readings were also helpful, such as the the Pomerance reading and the Naoroji one. Weakness: I would appreciate it if the class was structured a little better. Having a set schedule of when we actually met in class and when we had the day off would make it easier to plan ahead. Also, the breakout rooms in class time were sometimes quite awkward because no one would say anything and we would just be staring at blank space. I think class time could have been better if Professor Semmel did a little lecturing and we could ask him questions and have some back-and-forth.

STRENGTH: Prof Semmel cares a lot about his students, lighter workload, goes beyond Euro-centric POV (even at times actively criticizes it) despite that being Prof Semmel's field, TAs are quite helpful, readings were not overwhelming, genuinely enjoyable subject matter.

WEAKNESSES: Assignment dates got pushed back a lot which is normally fine but I picked the class because I thought I'd have the final paper done and turned in before reading period and instead it was due right at the start of reading period. Lectures felt a bit unorganized at times. I do not know if we made it to the end of the century. I think we only went from around like 1790-1860  with most content being from the early 1800s but it was hard to tell because the class was organized mores based on theme than chronology. I think just making it a bit more clear where we are situated would be nice.
I enjoyed the recorded lectures so I could speed up/go back to things I wanted to review. I also liked having the class time for group discussions to supplement the learning every week.

Strengths: interesting material, professor was very knowledgeable, readings were varied in terms of region, format, and topic. 
Weaknesses: sometimes had a hard time following along with the material, feedback on assignments was not always timely.
The strengths would be the discussion format and closeness with the TA/ULA. They are always there to help.
class gave a great survey of the world circa 1800, lecture format could be more organized, discussion sections were great

The strength of this course is that the workload is fairly light and the TFs are extremely helpful in providing feedbacks. The weakness of this class is that because the main focuses of the course were largely thematic, some of the pre-record lectures don't seem to relevant to the course which leaves students wondering what should be emphasized.
I really enjoyed the recorded lectures and how section discussion was structured. I feel like I got a much better wholistic view of the subject of history.

Do not think these issues will carry over in a post-COVID world, but: there should be no "recorded lectures" prior to our mandatory twice a week lecture. They would literally post anywhere from an hour to an hour and a half of recorded lectures prior to our twice a week lectures and section. Absolutely crazy.

Strengths: Great TF (Emmanuel), low workload, and (most likely) easy A. Some of the primary sources were interesting.
Weaknesses: Content was scattered and superficial. Prof. would randomly cancel class (although he would post recorded lectures).
The way discussion was set up made it easy to talk freely. Sometimes not all the readings were covered so they seemed irrelevant.

I think the Professor is really sweet but he seemed disorganized at times. Synchronous sessions were often canceled the day before, and he sent out email blasts with essay prompts instead of just using Canvas to have everything in one place

Strength: all history backgrounds were able to do well
Weakness: engagement in material was low

I think some strengths of the course were that you were given a fair workload each week. There was a nice mix of primary and secondary sources. For me, this was by far the most I had ever looked at primary sources and analyzed their significance. Another strength was the helping attitude of the professor and TA. My TA met with me one-on-one to improve all of my drafts before I submitted a final copy on each essay. The course material itself was very diverse and interesting, covering events from all corners of the globe. I do not think there were any weaknesses.

Strengths: Incredibly nice + caring professor & great TAs. Interesting content. Good primary sources. 

Weaknesses: I found the secondary sources to be a little out of place on occasion. Also, generally, organization was not a strong point. It wasn't a total mess, just not super well organized.
I prefer in person lectures to recorded lectures, finding recorded lectures less engaging especially when they are audio only.
Great discussions and really cool readings, even coming from the perspective of a non humanities major.

Though sometimes the course was a bit disorganized, I dont feel I suffered from that at all. On the contrary, I think Professor Semmel agonized about how to best present the class to us in a Zoom format and he did a great job, along with the TAs. I dont have anything negative to say at all.
Could be more asynchronous
Great class

The pre-recorded lectures were a huge plus in the course, probably my favorite part, as they got us the information without being too burdensome. One weakness was probably that readings and even the lectures were not integral to do well on papers.The TF-led sections are very important and enjoyable in learning the content.
It was a fun course! It was difficult for me to focus on lectures without pictures, but that will probably change during regular times.
This course was really chaotic and needed to be organized further in advance.

Strength - I definitely liked how Professor Semmel structured the class. The prerecorded lecture along with the weekly in-class discussions allowed me to process the material on my own time. 

Weakness - At times, it was difficult to stay engaged because the material covered was so vast (global history takes A LOT of time to unpack).
This course was too lenient. I felt like the professor was chill if we weren't motivated much to learn, he should have been stricter.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I do not think there is anything that can be done to further improve online learning at this point in the pandemic since we've been doing it for so long and tweaking our methods as we go.
The breakout rooms during class time were a little tough. It was kind of awkward and for the most part, no one would have their cameras on, making discussion difficult.
I loved the recorded lectures and the amount of group discussion during live classes.
The recorded lectures  were fantastic: they let you get the initial course material whenever worked for your schedule, and allowed the actual virtual class to be more engaging.
The recorded lectures were NOT it.
Recorded lectures before live class are nice. I wish their content was discussed a bit more in-depth.

I loved the recorded lectures. I think they were a strength of the course, especially the ones that some of the TA's did! They were very well-done and offered a lot of information jam-packed into a couple minutes
I think this course was well organized. Great balance of live sections and live class along with independent readings and lecture listening.
Section allowed for the most engagement

I think the workload was extremely fair due to the remote nature of learning. The professor made it clear that he wanted to make the class an enjoyable learning experience for everyone. Discussion sections were a great way to interact with other in ways you could not in the large lectures. I felt like the availability of the asynchronous lectures and the shortening of the synchronous lectures also made the material very easy to access. I never found myself getting bored in lecture as a result. I do not believe there were any improvements to be made.
I enjoyed the audio lectures.
The course was fine in an online format

I loved having prerecorded lectures, especially MP3 files, that I could listen to whenever on my own terms. I have ADHD and struggle with maintaining focus so having the ability to rewind and replay the lectures was a HUGE help. I really really wish all classes were required to record and post their lectures for this reason.
More virtual geared resources
Recorded lectures
The discussion sections were AMAZING!! It was just hard sometimes listening to the podcast lectures.
Did not like recorded audio lectures. I wish that the live zoom lectures had been more of a focus.
Professor Semmel's method of giving students a weekly break was very helpful in that it gave me, and the other students, a chance to actually rest in between classes and absorb the learned material.
I loved how flexible this course was. It allowed students to listen to lectures on their own time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course for a lowkey humanities credit. Professor Semmel is really understanding and laid-back. The workload really isn't too much, but readings/lectures can add up at times.

I would. It won't stress you out a ton, and there is something to learn no matter how much history you have learned. Since it is a pretty broad survey course, you will only get a sliver of each topic that on its own could be its own course, but I enjoyed the topics on ecology, disease, and discovery. It was a new and a different way of thinking about history. Also, Professor Semmel is very kind and is helpful when you meet with him. This class will most definitely be better in person as well, because he loves to have discussions that were difficult and awkward to have on zoom.
Absolutely! I think this is a great intro course into history. I enjoyed it a lot and would take it again.
Definitely! Fun course and not too difficult if you put in the effort to discuss and engage with your classmates.
I would recommend this class to a student. The workload is very low, the grading is very nice, and I feel like I actually learned a lot not only about history but how to view and analyze history.

Yes, for those looking for an introduction to global history. The class touches a ton of different topics and regions, so it may not be a good fit for those hoping to specialize in certain areas of focus specifically.
Yes, It was eye-opening and a very engaging course.
yes if they enjoy history and want to see it from a global perspective
Yes. I found this course to be a great compliment to the other classes I was taking.
I'd recommend this course to student who wants an easy humanities credit. However,  if you are looking for an interesting and engaging course, then this is not the course for you.

Yes! Not being a history major, I really appreciated thinking about history in an entirely new and modern way. While you definitely do learn names/dates/events in this class, what you really get out of it is a better understanding of how the modern world was shaped and how history is created.
It's a gut. Take it if you want an A. Otherwise you won't get anything else out of it.
If they are looking for an easy Humanities credit, in which they are most likely not going to learn much, then yes. Otherwise, no.
I think this is a good fifth class! Not too hard at all and you learn a lot. It's quite fun.
Given this was my first history course at Yale and I enjoyed it, I definitely would recommend it and perhaps take another one myself in the future.
Yes, if they are interested in world history and have a good knowledge of basic history.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The class offers students from all academic backgrounds the opportunity to learn history in a fun environment. There was very little pressure in this course because all of the assignments were essays that you had ample time to prepare for. The grading of the assignments was very fair and generous. The professor is very kind and helps all students perform to the best of their ability in the course. Lastly, the workload is extremely managable.

I would recommend this course (if taught by Semmel). He's an incredibly kind professor. The content is pretty neat  how all these different parts of the world connected in a time that most don't consider as incredibly intertwined. The readings are pretty good, very few duds. Coursework isn't intense, this is a good 4th in a heavy semester / 5th in a light.
It's a good introduction to global history and helps students get better acquainted with the field. Anyone wishing to develop broad knowledge about the world should take the class.

As a STEM major, I think this class was really cool and didn't assume any prior knowledge. It lets you get a little taste of everything. For a humanities major who is looking for something more in depthand organized about somethingmore specific,  maybe not.

Absolutely yes. This was my first history class at Yale and I learned a ton of extremely important information. I feel like I now can understand the current events of our world and contextualize them. If youre a history buff, maybe this class isnt for you.
Yes
I would recommend this course to another student because the workload is not bad, and it is an interesting course to take, especially if you need a humanities credit
Yes great professor
Absolutely, this was an amazing class!
Yes! It's a relatively easy and enjoyable history course, even for non-majors. Do not take it if you are looking for a super deep analysis of historical concepts.
For anyone who wants a strong understanding of places across the world in the 1800s, this is the perfect course!
Yes it was a very interesting and engaging course.
Probably not. It was too chaotic.

Yes! The structure of the class was unique and geared towards student learning. If you're looking to fulfill the distributional requirement, I recommend taking this course - especially if you're not a humanities person.
Maybe... It was an alright course but I have had better history courses
Yes I would recommend it to anyone interested in history.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of recorded lectures, live virtual lectures, and virtual sections.
Recorded lectures, live discussion sections
Recorded lectures and live virtual Zoom meetings with break-out rooms or large group discussions; also a discussion section every week
The lectures were prerecorded, but we still had virtual class where we sometimes listen to a lecture and other times did break out rooms.
recorded lecture and live virtual sessions
Also a lecture tuesday thursday
combination of virtual lecture and discussion section
We also had discussions in class and section, but we learned most through recorded lectures and readings.
There were also prerecorded lectures and a virtual discussion section.
The professor uploaded recorded lectures every week and we were expected to attend live virtual lecture occasionally for group activities.
There were recorded lectures, and the class periods were used as a way to interact with what we had listened to and read that week.
Also various recorded lectures.
The class was a combination of live virtual lectures (with mandatory attendance) and recorded lectures to be watched before the live lectures.
Recorded lectures, live virtual lectures, and discussion sections.
Combination of synchronous and asynchronous sessions
Recorded lectures and synchronous meetings
Live lecture
There were many pre-recorded lectures to listen to throughout each week. Also, there was one smaller discussion section every week.
Also had prerecorded audio lectures
Recorded lecture twice weekly plus a once weekly discussion section
Weekly discussion sections

recorded lecture

live virtual section

Our professor prerecorded lectures that he would post in advance. Our class time was spent over Zoom. He would sometimes lecture for a short while, then he would split us up into breakout rooms. It was almost like a seminar in that way.
Pre recorded resources
Synchronous sessions combines with pre recorded lectures
Section
live lecture with supplemental recorded lectures.
This course was likely the last during the pandemic, and it used a combination of pre-recorded mini-lectures and in-person discussions.
in-person lecture and discussion section along with recorded lectures
There were also recorded lectures and reading materials to prepare for class and section.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, and virtual discussion section.

Much of the course material was taught through prerecorded lectures. Occasionally, we discussed the lectures during the in-person class time but for the most part, section is where the majority of the material was unpacked.
Also pre-recorded lectures throughout the week and occasionally cancelled class and gave recordings instead
There was some live sessions, but mostly lectures were prerecorded and sent out for students to listen or view on their own time.
